item.title: Turkey and Syria Earthquake Death Toll Tops 7,700 As Rescuers Fight Weather
item.description: Shoveling snow and rubble, emergency crews worked across hundreds of miles in Turkey and Syria to save people in the aftermath of the most powerful quake in the region in decades.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur, Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers carrying Salih Polat, 27, from a collapsed building in Malatya, on Tuesday.

item.title: Videos Show Desperate Search for Survivors Near Quake’s Epicenter in Turkey
item.description: Hatay Province had Turkey’s highest-known death toll from Monday’s earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Tolga Ildun, Sarah Kerr, Axel Boada and Vivian Yee

item.title: Russia Pays a Bloody Price for Small Gains in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Russia is relying on masses of troops to overrun Ukrainian positions, producing heavy casualties and incremental gains.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: A billboard with an image of a Russian service member and a slogan reading “Glory to the Heroes of Russia!” in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: How Russia Is Surviving the Tightening Grip on Its Oil Revenue
item.description: Restrictions on Russia’s oil trade are raising the stakes in a protracted economic standoff that is reshaping the global energy market.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Stanley Reed
item.media:description: An oil tanker in Novorossiysk, Russia, in October. Russia is facing a gradual ratcheting up of Western oil sanctions.

item.title: As Sunak Tries to Move Ahead, He’s Haunted by Prime Ministers Past
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain made moves to recharge his government, but he is being harried by Liz Truss and Boris Johnson, who are not fading away.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain shuffled his cabinet on Tuesday.

item.title: China Tries to Play Down Balloon Dispute With Censorship and Memes
item.description: Chinese propaganda also appears to be walking a fine line: looking tough for the crowd at home, without further derailing relations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Outside the Foreign Ministry in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: In a First, South Korea Is Ordered to Compensate a Vietnam War Victim
item.description: A court ruling held that South Korean troops were responsible for a civilian massacre that killed more than 70 villagers in Vietnam during the war.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial site marks the area in Vietnam where South Korean marines were accused of killing more than 70 unarmed Vietnamese civilians in 1968.

item.title: David Carrick Is Sentenced to Life for Rape and Sexual Abuse
item.description: David Carrick had pleaded guilty to 49 crimes against 12 women in the latest case to cast a harsh spotlight on the Metropolitan Police.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Wiktor Szymanowicz/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Activists gathering for a protest outside Southwark Crown Court in London on Monday during the sentencing trial of David Carrick, a former police officer.

item.title: In Rural Ukraine, a Mobile Clinic Provides Medicine and Hope
item.description: A mobile clinic is trying to restore medical services to villages once occupied by Russian forces as fighting rages nearby. “They’ll never beat our people,” a specialist with the team said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Bid to Improve Food Production? Giant Towers of Pigs.
item.description: High-rise hog farms have sprung up nationwide as part of Beijing’s drive to enhance its agricultural competitiveness and reduce its dependence on imports.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

item.title: Syrian Refugees Who Died in Turkey Earthquake Are Returned Home
item.description: “Those who died, we want them to come back,” said Ahmad Yousef, who was waiting to receive the body of a cousin’s daughter. “We want them to be buried among their family.”
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Muhammad Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrian refugees who had fled to Turkey during a civil war were pulled from the rubble of their new homes and repatriated after the earthquake.

item.title: Grieving Turkish Diaspora Rallies to Support Turkey Earthquake Victims
item.description: In Melbourne, Australia, dozens of volunteers in the parking lot behind a halal butcher shop packed three shipping containers with cardboard boxes full of new tents, blankets and sleeping bags.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Members of the Turkish Australian community in Melbourne, Australia, packing tents, blankets and sleeping bags to be shipped to earthquake victims in Turkey.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The rising death toll in Turkey and Syria from the earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a collapsed building in Malatya, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Focuses on Domestic Issues in State of the Union Despite Global Tensions
item.description: Mr. Biden is proud of reshaping foreign policy to focus on superpower conflict, but knows it is jobs and energy prices that voters want to hear about.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Oksana Markarova, the Ukrainian ambassador, was a guest at the State of the Union address, as she was last year, but President Biden mentioned Ukraine only briefly this time.

item.title: After Spy Balloon Clash, U.S.-China Tensions Loom Over Biden’s Speech
item.description: The president has taken steps meant to limit China’s technological advancement and bolster military forces in the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden has taken economic and military steps aimed at limiting China.

item.title: After Spy Balloon Incident, China Rejects Pentagon’s Request to Speak
item.description: Chinese officials rejected a request from the U.S. defense secretary to speak with his counterpart after an American fighter jet shot down a Chinese spy balloon.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chad Fish/Chad Fish, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The balloon after it was downed on Saturday. Navy divers are trying to recover its sensors and other surveillance equipment.

item.title: Felipe Calderón, Former Mexican President, Accused of Supporting Sinaloa Cartel
item.description: The accusation, which was quickly denied, was made by a former Mexican official at the trial in Brooklyn of Mexico’s former top security chief.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Susana Gonzalez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Felipe Calderón during an interview with The New York Times at his office in 2011, when he was the president of Mexico.

item.title: Baby Born in Rubble of Turkey-Syria Earthquake is One of Many Child Victims
item.description: Harrowing images have emerged of some of the millions of children caught in the catastrophic earthquake in Turkey and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A baby girl who was born under the rubble caused by an earthquake received treatment at a children’s hospital in the town of Afrin, Aleppo province, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Mukarram Jah, Heir to an Opulent Throne He Abandoned, Dies at 89
item.description: He descended from famed Islamic royalty in India and Turkey, but later fled to Australia and became a sheep farmer.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Mr. Jah with Princess Esra, center, at Chowmahalla Palace in Hyderabad in 1967, the year he was crowned nizam.

item.title: Joy and Heartache Follow Earthquake Rescue in Turkish City of Gaziantep
item.description: In the hard-hit Turkish city of Gaziantep, a collapsed apartment building spared few of its residents. But one man heard his brother’s voice from beneath the debris.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Quake’s Death Toll Soars
item.description: Also, China’s balloon spin and Russia’s mounting losses.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: After an intensive search, rescue workers saved Vacit Amuri, a 3-year-old girl from a Syrian family, from a collapsed building on Tuesday.

item.title: At Cooper Union, a Russian Design Show Caught in a Political Crossfire
item.description: After indefinitely postponing a modest student exhibit about the Russian equivalent to the Bauhaus, the school received protests from 750 academics. On Monday, it reinstated the show.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Giovannini
item.category: Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Bokov, an assistant adjunct professor, outside Cooper Union, in a neighborhood known as Little Ukraine. Her exhibition about a century-old Moscow design school was postponed when an article raised questions about its timing. On Monday, the school reinstated the show.

item.title: 3 E.U. Countries Plan to Get Some Leopard 1 Tanks to Ukraine ‘Within Months’
item.description: The new initiative aims to boost Kyiv’s supply of tanks faster as more advanced tanks will take many months to arrive.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Leopard 1 A5 tanks in a production facility in Germany.

item.title: Erdogan’s Response to Turkey’s Earthquake Could Determine His Re-Election
item.description: The Turkish president swept to power two decades ago after the government botched its response to a 1999 earthquake. Monday’s quake adds to his challenges an election just a few months away.
item.dc:creator: Gulsin Harman and Matt Surman
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara in January.

item.title: Pentagon Lifts Trump-Era Ban on Release of Guantánamo Prisoners’ Art
item.description: The Trump administration called detainee art U.S. government property and halted most releases. Lawyers never mounted an intellectual property case.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The prisoner Mohammed Ahmed Ghulam Rabbani painted this scene at Guantánamo Bay and gave it to a lawyer before the Trump administration banned all such releases in 2017. Mr. Rabbani, who is one of 20 prisoners eligible for transfer, wants to take with him all the paintings he has at the prison when he is repatriated to Pakistan.

item.title: The Sole Border Crossing for U.N. Aid From Turkey to Syria Is Blocked
item.description: As the Syrian government tightly controls what aid it allows into opposition-held areas, border crossings with Turkey have been a lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Mourning victims of the earthquake in Jandaris, a town in the opposition-held part of Aleppo Province, in Syria on Tuesday.

item.title: Soccer Player Christian Atsu Is Rescued From Turkey Earthquake
item.description: Just hours before Christian Atsu was trapped, he had scored the winning goal for the Turkish soccer club Hatayspor.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: Christian Atsu in 2019. He was injured in the earthquake, according to the vice president of the Turkish club he plays for.

item.title: Searching for Survivors
item.description: Time is running out, and cold weather is impeding the search for survivors after a major earthquake hit Turkey.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Searching for survivors in Adana, Turkey, this morning.

item.title: ‘Miracle’ Cystic Fibrosis Drug Kept Out of Reach in Developing Countries
item.description: Vertex Pharmaceuticals is not making its drug, Trikafta, available in poorer countries, where thousands of diagnosed patients stand to benefit.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shwetha Sree, left, with her 5-year-old son Vihaan, who has cystic fibrosis. He would be eligible for Vertex’s drug on his 6th birthday were he to live in the U.S.

item.title: How Deepfake Videos Are Used to Spread Disinformation
item.description: For the first time, A.I.-generated personas, often used for corporate trainings, were detected in a state-aligned information campaign — opening a new chapter in online manipulation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur

item.title: Turkey Earthquake: Time Is Running Out to Find Survivors
item.description: Rescues typically happen within three days of an earthquake, an expert said. The logistics of finding survivors in Turkey and Syria are daunting.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono

item.title: The Quest to Find Rectangles in a Square
item.description: A puzzle posted in an online community unlocked a wormhole within the basic shape.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: One Turkish Apartment Tower Collapsed in The Earthquake, While Those Around It Did Not
item.description: Rescue workers listened for signs of survivors in the rubble as residents wondered why their homes had not fallen.
item.dc:creator: Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency personnel during a search and rescue operation at the site of a collapsed building in Adana, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: The U.S. aid agency deploys two search and rescue teams to Turkey.
item.description: The two units, based in Virginia and California, are the only such teams in the United States that work internationally. They join the thousands of rescuers from Syria and Turkey already there.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Members of the Los Angeles County Fire Department preparing for deployment to Turkey on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Could Leave Ukraine to Visit EU Leaders in Brussels
item.description: The Ukrainian president’s possible visit to the Belgian capital, where he would likely address the European Parliament, hinges on security arrangements.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at a meeting with European Union leaders in Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: These Are the Deadliest Earthquakes of the 21st Century
item.description: Officials in both Syria and Turkey expect the death toll to rise significantly as rescuers make their way through devastated cities.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A woman walking through Port-au-Prince in 2010 after a 7.0 quake hit Haiti, killing over 200,000 people.

item.title: How to Help Earthquake Victims in Turkey and Syria
item.description: Here’s how to contribute to organizations that are aiding the rescue and recovery efforts in Turkey and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: Injured earthquake survivors waiting to be treated at the entrance of a hospital on Monday in Iskenderun, Turkey.

item.title: Russian Attacks Intensify in Eastern Ukraine Ahead of Expected Offensive
item.description: Russia is deploying hundreds of thousands of newly mobilized soldiers, in small groups, to probe for vulnerabilities in Ukrainian defensive lines.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tatyana, 51, and her sister Halina, 56, hugged goodbye as Halina prepared to evacuate the village of Nevske in eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Powerful Quake Strikes Turkey and Syria, Killing More Than 4,300
item.description: Desperate survivors dug through rubble with shovels and their bare hands, hoping to find loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers attempting a search and rescue operation at the site of a collapsed building in Adana, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Devastating Quake
item.description: Also, a Chinese balloon floats over Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Rescuers searched for victims and survivors amidst the rubble of a building that collapsed in Adana, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: Humanitarian Crisis in Syria Is Exacerbated By Deadly Earthquakes
item.description: One of the hardest hit areas was northwestern Syria, where nearly three million people displaced by the country’s decade-long civil war were already living in precarious conditions.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Raja Abdulrahim and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Searching for victims and survivors amid the rubble of collapsed buildings on Monday in the village of Besnia in Idlib Province in northwest Syria.

item.title: For Syrians Who Endured a Brutal Civil War, an Earthquake Is a Reminder
item.description: “My mind was playing tricks on me, telling me it was war again,” said Osama Salloum, a doctor from Idlib.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Hwaida Saad and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:description: Syrian rescuers retrieved an injured man from the rubble of a collapsed building in Azaz, Aleppo Province, on Monday.

item.title: Despite an Enormous Rescue Effort in Turkey, Many People Are Waiting For Help
item.description: So many people are trapped in the rubble, injured or lacking shelter that aid efforts are overwhelmed, witnesses say.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur and Gulsin Harman

item.title: Turkey Hit By Unusually Large Aftershock After First Earthquake
item.description: Aftershocks normally follow a large earthquake, but they are rarely as powerful as the 7.5 magnitude tremor that came after the 7.8 shock in Turkey on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Search and rescue operations in Diyarbakir, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: Kamala Harris Announces Funding to Address Migration Crisis
item.description: The vice president said private companies had pledged almost $1 billion to support communities in Central America.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crossings at the U.S.-Mexico border remain at record highs, posing logistical and humanitarian challenges for President Biden.

item.title: Another Chinese Balloon Flew Over Colombia, Officials Confirm
item.description: The Chinese government said the balloon that Colombia spotted in its airspace on Friday was for civilian purposes and was being used for flight tests.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A Chinese balloon floating off the coast of South Carolina before being shot down by an American fighter jet on Saturday.

item.title: Parts of Ancient Gaziantep Castle Collapsed in the Earthquake in Turkey
item.description: Parts of stone walls and iron railings collapsed around the castle, parts of which date to the second and third centuries, according to a Turkish state-run news agency.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mehmet Akif Parlak/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Gaziantep Castle in Turkey sustained major damage during the earthquake on Monday.

item.title: Eastern Ukraine Braces for New Russian Offensive
item.description: The war is intensifying in a string of villages on the eastern front, where doctors struggle to handle an influx of gruesome injuries and soldiers fret about a Russian army sending waves of new conscripts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loved ones at the funeral of a Ukrainian soldier, Anton Pushkar, who died in the fighting near Bakhmut, in Kharkiv on Monday.

item.title: U.K. Court Hears Details of David Carrick’s Years of Sexual Abuse
item.description: A sentencing hearing for David Carrick, who pleaded guilty to 49 counts of sexual assault and rape involving at least a dozen women over 17 years, revealed new details of his shocking abuse.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the London Assembly’s Police and Crime Committee, an oversight panel, questioned police officials about the Carrick case in January.

item.title: What It Takes to Keep the Keeling Curve Going
item.description: Ever since an eruption in Hawaii halted a long-running record of carbon dioxide, scientists have found ways to carry on — atop a neighboring volcano.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: Aidan Colton, an atmospheric technician with NOAA, held his breath while collecting an air sample atop Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

item.title: Avalanches in Alps Kill at Least 11, as Weather Hampers Rescues
item.description: Deaths were reported in Austria, Italy and Switzerland over the weekend. Heavy snowfall and high winds have increased the danger for skiers, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Rescuers after an avalanche on Saturday near the town of Fieberbrunn in western Austria.

item.title: Russia’s Foreign Minister Lavrov Heads to Mali
item.description: Mali said it and Russia will seek to strengthen security and defense ties, in a country where Russia already provides helicopters and mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Sergei Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, meeting with South Africa’s Foreign Minister, Naledi Pandor, in Pretoria last month. Mr. Lavrov will visit Mali on Monday, in his third visit to Africa in about six months.

item.title: China’s Balloon Dispute Aims Attention at Xi’s Leadership
item.description: The flap with the United States raises concerns about how China wields its power in a climate where one wrong move could set off an accidental conflict.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Mao Ning, a Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman, fielding questions about the stray balloon that traversed the United States, at a news conference in Beijing on Monday.
